title-group.article-title: Modeling Impact Energy of Functionally Graded Steels in Crack Divider Configuration Using Modified Stress–Strain Curve Data

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Technical and Engineering Sciences, Islamic Azad University (Saveh Branch), Hezar, Iran
2Department of Mining and Metallurgical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, 424, Hafez Avenue, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. E-mail: alinazari84@aut.ac.ir

abstract.p: Charpy impact energy of functionally graded steels produced by electroslag remelting composed of graded ferritic and austenitic layers together with bainite or martensite intermediate layer in crack divider configuration has been modeled. From load–displacement curves acquired from instrumented Charpy impact test for original ferritic and original austenitic steels together with single-phase bainitic and martensitic specimens, the obtained stress–strain curves from uniaxial tensile tests were modified. Afterward, Charpy impact energy of each constituent layer was assumed to be proportional to the area under modified stress–strain curve and Charpy impact energy of the functionally graded composites was determined analytically through the rule of mixtures. A good agreement between experimental results and the results obtained from analytical model was observed.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Evaluations on damage of the composite and functionally graded structures are very interesting fields in mechanics of materials (Tay et al., 2008; Haj-Ali, 2009). Charpy V-notch impact test is a widely used test on notched specimens which are submitted to the impact of a hammer with the given kinetic energy to investigate damage behavior of materials (Vodopivec et al., 2003). Some researchers have tried to model Charpy impact behavior of monolithic materials mathematically (Xi, 1995; Sreenivasan and Mannan, 2000; Fengchun et al., 2004; Heerens et al., 2005; Tanguy et al., 2005). Although some of these models seem promising, none of these works show realistic results because of their simplifications and assumptions. Therefore, several works have been carried out by focusing on the evaluation of impact behavior that utilizes more accurate instrumented Charpy impact test (Seidler and Grellmann, 1995; Rossoll et al., 2002; Sreenivasan et al., 2004; Dai and Marmy, 2005). Also, some models have been recently proposed to model Charpy impact behavior using neural network (Cottrell et al., 2007; Pak et al., 2009); these models are at their infancy and need to be extended.

Very few fracture experiments, particularly dynamic fracture, of functionally gradient materials have been reported. Among them, crack tip deformation and fracture parameter history in functionally graded glass-filled epoxy were evaluated for low velocity impact loading by Rousseau and Tippur (2001). Guo and Noda (2008) studied the dynamic response of a functionally graded layered structure with a crack crossing the interface with in-plane impact loading condition. Xu et al. (2008) investigated the plane strain problem of semi-infinite cracks in an infinite functionally graded orthotropic material with opening and in-plane shear impact loading modes. Bezensek and Hancock (2007) studied the toughness of laser welded joints of low alloy steel under mode I and mixed mode configuration along with Charpy impact tests.

Transformation characteristics (Aghazadeh and Shahosseinie, 2005) like tensile strength (Aghazadeh and Shahosseinie, 2006), Charpy impact energy (Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2009, 2010a, b), and fracture toughness (Aghazadeh et al., 2010; Nazari et al., 2010) of FGSs have been modeled previously. Charpy impact energy of αβγ and γMγ FGSs with crack divider configuration as shown in Figure 1(a) has been modeled previously by two methods. In both methods, Charpy impact energy of the composite was considered to be the sum of the Charpy impact energy of constituent layers by means of the rule of mixtures. In one method, Charpy impact energy of each layer was related to the area under stress–strain curve of that layer (Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b) and in the other model, the Charpy impact energy of each layer was related to the Vickers microhardness of that layer (Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2009). Although the experimental results of the impact energy of the composites showed a good agreement with those obtained from analytical models, some deviations between the results were observed for composites containing martensite layer. These deviations may be modified by more accurate assumptions. Thus, in this study, Charpy impact energy of FGSs in crack divider configuration has been analytically modeled based on the modified stress–strain curves of the constituent layers. The stress–strain curve of the constituent layers has been modified using instrumented Charpy impact test data of the corresponding layer and then the area under stress–strain curve of each layer has been assumed to be proportional to the Charpy impact energy of the corresponding layer. Charpy impact energy of the composite has been determined by the sum of the Charpy impact energy of the composite’s constituent layers according to the rule of mixtures. Figure 1.
(a) Schematic representation of composite Charpy test specimens in the form of crack divider and (b) dimensions of Charpy impact specimen.

sec.title: EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURE
sec.p:
Similar to the previous works (Aghazadeh and Shahosseinie, 2005, 2006; Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2009, 2010a, b; Aghazadeh et al., 2010; Nazari et al., 2010), to produce FGSs, a miniature ESR apparatus was utilized. The slag was a mixture of 20% CaO, 20% Al2O3, and 60% CaF2. Commercial-type AISI 1020 (

Remelting was carried out under a constant power supply of 16 kVA. After remelting, composite ingots were hot-pressed at 980°C down to the thickness of 10 mm followed by air-cooling.

The impact energy of FGSs in crack divider configuration was evaluated by Charpy impact test at 18°C using standard sized specimens (10 × 10 × 50 mm3) according to the ASTM E23 (2001). The dimension of the specimens is shown in Figure 1(b). From each hot-pressed composite, five specimens were examined for Charpy impact test and the average value was reported as the Charpy impact energy of that specimen. In addition, the best curve obtained from the average values was adopted for load–displacement curve of each specimen.

Instrumented Charpy impact test was conducted on as-received ferritic and austenitic steels which were annealed at 980°C and air-cooled and single-phase bainite and martensite with composition and mechanical properties analogous to the bainite and martensite layers. The production method of single-phase specimens with chemical composition and mechanical properties identical to the bainitic and martensitic layers was similar to the previous works (Aghazadeh and Shahosseinie, 2006; Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b). To do this, Charpy impact specimens of the same composition and mechanical properties to bainitic and martensitic layers were produced. Initially, the average chemical composition of the bainite and martensite layers was obtained (Table 2). Afterward, bainitic and martensitic samples with composition in accordance to the average composition of bainitic and martensitic layers were produced by means of a vacuum induction furnace. Similar to the primary composites, single-phase specimens were hot-pressed at 980°C and air-cooled. Through trial and error (i.e., confirming the chemical composition and changing the cooling rate), the samples with the nearest hardness to single-phase bainitic and martensitic layers were selected and Charpy impact specimens from the bainitic and martensitic samples were made. Table 2.
Chemical composition (wt%) of bainitic and martensitic layers together with the single-phase bainite and martensite specimens produced from samples.
Specimen studied Pct Cr Pct Ni Pct C Pct Si Pct Mn Pct S Pct P
Single-phase bainite 14.5 7.2 0.12 0.8 1.8 0.03 0.04
Bainite specimen produced from the sample 14.7 7.15 0.13 0.85 1.9 0.032 0.045
Single-phase martensite 7.3 3.2 0.19 0.39 0.3 0.04 0.05
Martensite specimen produced from the sample 7.38 3.14 0.21 0.28 0.28 0.033 0.055

Tensile tests were carried out on ferritic steel, austenitic steel, single-phase bainite, and single-phase martensite under an extension rate of 0.1 mm/s according to the ASTM E8 (2001) standard. Specimen dimensions are shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Dimensions of tensile specimen (mm).
For metallographic examinations, the plates were sliced, ground, polished, and etched in a ‘Kalling’ solution and 1 pct ‘Nital’.
Vickers microhardness tests were carried out using 100 g weight to evaluate microhardness profile and to verify the location of bainite or martensite intermediate layers.

sec.title: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sec.p:
Figure 3(a)–(e) illustrates Vickers microhardness profile of the produced composites. For each layer, instead of using the average values, the variations of the Vickers microhardness have been illustrated and therefore a band has showed the Vickers microhardness as an alternative of a line. The thickness of martensite layer is 1.5 mm and that of bainite is 0.6 mm, which was verified by Vickers microhardness examination and is in accordance to the previous works (Aghazadeh and Shahosseinie, 2005, 2006; Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2009, 2010a, b; Aghazadeh et al., 2010; Nazari et al., 2010). In addition, Figure 4(a) and (b) shows the formation of bainite and martensite layers in the produced composites. Figure 3.
Microhardness profile of the hot-pressed: (a) αβγ, (b) γMγ, (c) αβγβα, (d) γβαβγ, and (e) αβγMγ composites. Figure 4.
Microstructure of (a) bainite layer formed in αβγ composite and (b) martensite layer formed between two layers of austenitic region in γMγ composite.

Impact energy of the composites is shown in Table 3 and that of single-phase specimens is shown in Table 4. The calculation method of uncertainty was in accordance to the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST, 2008) method for Charpy impact test machines and it is as follows. A Charpy laboratory will typically compute the sample mean (CV) and sample standard deviation (S.D.) of n specimens of the test material using Equations (1) and (2): (1) (2) where CVi represents the values of Charpy impact energy in each experiment. The degrees of freedom (df) associated with the sample standard deviation, s, are n − 1. It is important to note that s includes all sources of random error, including machine variability, material variability, and the typical variations expected when following the standard test procedure. The individual components of the random error cannot be estimated separately in the case of destructive impact testing (multiple measurements on the same specimen are needed to do this). In addition, random errors (unlike systematic errors) do not remain constant during the measurement of n specimens; so, these errors do not result in a bias (NIST, 2008).

The corrected mean CV (CVcorrected) value after applying systematic effect could be written as (NIST, 2008): (3) where b∧ is the difference between the verification result for the test machine and the certified value of the verification specimens and êsystematic the systematic errors due to all other factors that are not already included in the machine bias.

Assuming all the terms in CVcorrected are independent, the combined standard uncertainty of CVcorrected is (NIST, 2008): (4) where u(CVcorrected) is the combined standard uncertainty of CVcorrected, u(b∧) and u(êsystematic) the uncertainty values associated with b∧ and êsystematic, respectively.

An uncertainty interval with 100(1 − α)% coverage probability (α is 0.05 for 95% coverage) is given by: (5) where t1-α2.dfeff is found in a t-table (NIST, 2008). Using a t-table, we get a coverage factor of 2.012 for testing five specimens. NIST (2008) has been proposed b∧=-4.2J, êsystematic = 3J and u(êsystematic) = 0.6J for Charpy impact energies in the range of our values in this study. As shown in Table 3, the uncertainty for the composites containing martensite layer has a wider range. The presence of martensite layer causes a broad range of impact energy acquiring from testing similar specimens. For comparison between Charpy impact energy of the specimens, the mean CV value of the composites has been considered.

Table 3 shows that the impact energy of the composites without martensite layer (i.e., αβγ, γβαβγ and αβγβα composites) is more than that of composites containing martensite layer (i.e., γMγ and αβγMγ composites). In αβγ, γβαβγ, and αβγβα composites, an improvement of impact energy with respect to
α
˙
steel is observed. Regardless of containing phases, the arrangement of the primary electrode pieces is a key factor to affect the morphology of the produced composites and thus their impact energy, whereas the bainite layer in αβγ, γβαβγ, and αβγβα composites improves the impact energy. The improvement of impact energy in αβγ, γβαβγ, and αβγβα composites is mainly due to bainite formation and the presence of austenite phase with relatively high impact energy with respect to
α
˙
steel. In γMγ and αβγMγ composites, the sharp interface (Figure 5(b)) between martensite layer and neighboring austenitic regions causes so large different crack growth rates in the two neighboring phases (i.e., martensite and austenite phases) that one may imagine the martensite layer cross out the continuality of the functionally graded composites. Figure 5.
True stress–strain curve of constituent phases of composites.

To model Charpy impact energy of the composites analytically, the stress–strain curve of each layer was obtained in accordance to the previous works (Aghazadeh and Shahosseinie, 2006; Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b) and then the stress–strain curves were modified using the data acquired from instrumented Charpy impact tests conducted on single-phase α˙, γ·, bainite and martensite specimens. To model Charpy impact energy of functionally graded αβγ composite, it may be considered as a combination of alpha region with mα layers, single-phase bainite and gamma region with nγ layers (Figure 3(a)). Assuming, the area under stress–strain curve of each layer is related to its Charpy impact energy, one may relate the impact energy of a layered composite with crack divider configuration to the corresponding area under stress–strain curve of each layer. Following Atkins and Mai (1985), Charpy impact energy of the composite was related to the impact energy of the individual layer (i.e., the area under modified stress–strain curve of each layer) combined with Charpy impact energy of the single-phase bainite according to the rule of mixtures.

Stress–strain curves of single-phase bainite–original ferritic steel and single–phase bainite–original austenitic steel have been plotted in Figure 5. Stress–strain curve of each layer in α and γ graded regions may be represented by several curves according to the number of layers and could be represented as α1, α2,…,αm in alpha region and as γ1, γ2,…, γn in gamma region. The area under stress–strain curve of original austenite is larger than that of single-phase bainite and that of single-phase bainite is larger than the area under stress–strain curve of original ferrite (Table 2). In this way, the corresponding area under stress–strain curve of each layer increases from α· layer (i.e., the first layer of the graded alpha region, α1) toward γ· layer (i.e., the last layer of the graded gamma region, γn). Also, it is assumed that the yield stress of each element is proportional to the Vickers microhardness of that element. Therefore, the yield stress of each element in α and γ regions should also obey the hardness pattern. The yield stress of each element may be related to the Vickers microhardness of that element as (Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b); (6) (7) where σy(α·), σy(γ·), and σy(β) are yield stresses of original ferrite, original austenite, and bainite layer, respectively; VH(αi) and VH(γi) the Vickers microhardness values of each element in α and γ regions, respectively; and VH(α·), VH(γ·), and VHβ the Vickers microhardness values of original ferrite, original austenite, and bainite layer, respectively.

Assuming the stress–strain curve of each element obeys the Holloman relation (Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b), the imposed stress to each element at yield strain of bainitic layer may be given as; (8) (9) where
σ ′
i
and
σ ″
i
are the imposed stress to each element in α and γ regions at yield strain of bainitic layer, respectively; εβ the yield strain of the bainitic layer; and n(αi) and n(γi) the strain-hardening coefficients of each element in α and γ regions, respectively. The work hardening coefficient of each element in the composite was supposed to obey exponential function, therefore (Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b); (10) (11) where n(α·), n(γ·), and nβ are the strain-hardening coefficients of original ferrite, original austenite, and bainite layer at distance X, respectively; Xα·, Xγ·, and Xβ the distances of original ferrite, original austenite, and bainite layers from specimen edge, respectively; and ε(αi) and ε(γi) in Equations (8) and (9) are the yield strain values of each layer in α and γ regions, respectively.
By considering the boundary conditions;

Similarly,
where ɛ(α·), ɛ(γ·), and ε(β) are the yield strain values of original ferrite, original austenite, and bainitic layers, respectively.
The yield strain of each element in regions α and γ of the composite is as follows (Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b): (12) (13) where E is the Young’s modulus.

Therefore, the stress–strain curve of each element could be determined. Furthermore, an exponential relation may be assumed for a curve linking fracture point of the stress–strain curves of original ferrite and single-phase bainite, and original austenite and single-phase bainite (i.e., the dashed connecting curves shown in Figure 5) with suitable boundary conditions as follows: (14) (15) where σts(α·), σts(γ·), and σts(β) are the ultimate tensile stress values of original ferrite, original austenite, and bainite layers, respectively, and ɛts(α·), ɛts(γ·), and εts(β) the ultimate tensile strain of original ferrite, original austenite, and bainite layers, respectively.

By combining the Holloman relation for each element and Equations (14) and (15) for α and γ regions, respectively, tensile stress and strain of each element could be determined (Aghazadeh and Shahosseinie, 2006; Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b).

In order to take into account the effects of strain rate under impact loading, the stress–strain curve of each layer was modified as follows: at first, consider the load–displacement curve obtained from instrumented Charpy impact test conducted on original ferritic steel (Figure 6(a)). This curve shows that the load increases proportionally to the deflection up to the point A, where plastic strain is started. The deflection force increases up to the maximum load at the point B. Beyond this point, the load decreases in a non-linear manner with increasing deflection to the point C. Afterward, it falls off due to unstable crack propagation. Up to point A, the specimen is bended elastically and the load increases proportional to the deflection. Figure 6.
Smoothened load–displacement obtained from instrumented Charpy impact test of (a) original ferritic steel, (b) original austenitic steel, (c) single-phase bainite, and (d) single-phase martensite. Points A, B, and C are determined from the mean value of five tested specimens and then the curve has schematically been illustrated to represent Charpy impact energy. For martensitic specimen point B does not appear for its negligible plastic deformation.

Consider an elastically deflected impact specimen with curvature R and deflection value δe, according to Figure 7. Based on Von Mises’ criteria, the maximum stress in elastic region for a monolithic material with yield stress under impact loading of σY,impact is determined when: (16) where σxx, σyy, and σzz are the principal stress in x, y, and z directions, respectively. Figure 7.
Schematic representation of a deflected Charpy impact specimen up to its maximum elastic deflection.
By applying the stress states given in Equation (17), it could be written as follows: (18)
The elastic strain in the x direction could be written as (Hertzberg, 1996); (19)
Therefore, σY,impact could be determined from Equation (18).

Strain rate sensitivity of original ferritic steel was determined and similarly, strain rate sensitivity of original austenite steel and single-phase bainite was also determined. Considering an exponential relation for variation of strain rate sensitivities of each layer in the graded α and γ regions, it could be written; (27) (28) where m(αi) and m(γi) are strain rate sensitivity values of each layer in graded α and γ regions, respectively; and m(α·), m(γ·), and m(β) the strain rate sensitivity values of original ferrite, original austenite, and single-phase bainite, respectively.

Therefore, the yield stress under impact loading for each layer in graded α and γ regions could be written as: (29) (30) where σY,impact(αi) and σY,impact(γi) are the yield stress values under impact loading for each layer in graded α and γ regions, respectively.

Also, the yield strain under impact loading for each layer in graded α and γ regions may be written as; (31) (32) where εY,impact(αi) and εY,impact(γi) are the yield strain under impact loading for each layer in graded α and γ regions, respectively.

To determine the modified Holloman Relation for each layer in graded α and γ regions, the work-hardening coefficient of the layers under impact loading is determined as: (33) (34) where σY,impact(α0), σY,impact(γ0), and σY,impact(β) are the yield stress values of original ferrite, original austenite, and single-phase bainite under impact loading, respectively; εY,impact(α0), εY,impact(γ0), and υY,impact(β) the yield strain values of original ferrite, original austenite, and single-phase bainite under impact loading, respectively; n′(αi) and n′(γi) the work-hardening coefficients of the layers under impact loading in graded α and γ regions, respectively.

The constant K′ of the modified Holloman relation for each layer in graded α and γ regions could be obtained as: (35) (36) where K′(αi) and K′(γi) are the modified constants of Holloman relation for each layer in graded α and γ regions, respectively.

Also, the modified tensile stress of each layer in graded α and γ regions could be written as: (37) (38) where σts,impact(αi) and σts,impact(γi) are the tensile stress values under impact loading for each layer in graded α and γ regions, respectively.

Finally, the tensile strain of each layer in graded α and γ regions could be written as: (39) (40) where εY,impact(αi) and σY,impact(γi) are the tensile strain values under impact loading for each layer in graded α and γ regions, respectively.

Also for gamma region, the stress–strain curve could be modified by the same procedure. Afterward, by integrating the modified Holloman relation corresponding to each stress–strain curve in the range of yield strain to tensile strain, in addition to the area under elastic portion of stress–strain curve, the total area under stress–strain curve of each layer could be determined as follows; (41) (42) where Smodified(αi) and Smodified(γi) are the area under stress–strain curve of each layer in graded alpha and gamma regions.

Subsequently, the impact energy of αβγ composite could be obtained by relating the Charpy impact energy of each layer to the corresponding area under modified stress–strain curve of that layer utilizing suitable functions (exponential function, Equation (43), homographic function, Equation (44), and power-law function, Equation (45)) such as previous work (Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b). (43) (44) (45) where A and B are the appropriate values which could be determined from the following boundary conditions for alpha region:
and the following ones for gamma region
where CV(α·), CV(γ·), and CV(β) are Charpy impact energy values of original ferrite, original austenite, and bainite layer, respectively; and Smodified(α·), Smodified(γ·), and Smodified(β) the corresponding area under modified stress–strain curve of original ferrite, original austenite, and bainite layer, respectively.

Finally, by applying the rule of mixtures, Charpy impact energy of αβγ composite is determined as following utilizing exponential function, Equation (46), homographic function, Equation (47), and power-law function, Equation (48): (46) (47) (48) where CV(αi) and CV(γi) are Charpy impact energy values of each layer in graded alpha and gamma regions, respectively; Smodified(αi) and Smodified(γi) the corresponding area under modified stress–strain curve of each layer in graded alpha and gamma regions, respectively; Vi the volume fraction of each element in α and γ regions; and Vβ the volume fraction of bainite layer.

Considering the thickness of each layer is 10 µm in accordance to the previous works (Aghazadeh and Shahosseinie, 2006; Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b), and the maximum and minimum values of Vickers microhardness in each layer, the range of Charpy impact energy for αβγ composite was determined and it is shown in Figure 8. It also shows the experimental range of acquired Charpy impact energy for αβγ composite. Apparently, the calculation method based on the modified stress–strain curves of the constituent layers could represent accurate range of the obtained Charpy impact energy. Figure 8.
Experimental and analytical Charpy impact energy of composites.

Charpy impact energy of γMγ, αβγβα, γβαβγ, and αβγMγ composites was also modeled similar to the procedure which was carried out for αβγ composite. For αβγMγ composite (Figure 3(e)), the intermediate γ layer (γII which exactly is placed at the middle of this γ layer with 6 mm thickness) has a different microhardness than the primary γ layer; thus, it must have a different impact energy than the primary austenite. To measure the impact energy of this layer, the intermediate gamma region was divided into three regions as γI, γII, and γIII. Given the average concentration of γII as pct Cr = 16.1, pct Ni = 8.06, pct C = 0.08, pct Mn = 1.9, pct P = 0.04, and pct S = 0.03, tensile and instrumented Charpy impact tests for γII were carried out and the results are shown in Table 3. The range of Charpy impact energy obtained from the analytical model for γMγ, αβγβα, γβαβγ, and αβγMγ composites is also illustrated in Figure 8. Again, there is a good agreement between experimental results and those acquired from the analytical model by utilizing different functions even for the composites containing martensite layer which their impact energy was not properly predicted by the previous model (Nazari and Aghazadeh, 2010b). Seemingly, modifying the stress–strain curve and taking into account the uncertainty of Charpy impact test would outcome in accurate results.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: Charpy impact energy of functionally graded composites with graded alpha and gamma regions together with newly formed bainite and martensite intermediate layers has been modeled based on the rule of mixtures. Three types of suitable functions (i.e. exponential, homographic, and power-law functions) were utilized to correlate Charpy impact energy of each constituent layer of the composites to its corresponding area under modified stress–strain curve. The modification of stress–strain curves was performed utilizing the data acquired from instrumented Charpy impact tests of original ferrite, original austenite, and single-phase bainitic and martensitic specimens. The results obtained from the analytical model by using all three functions are in good agreement with those obtained from the experiments. However, the maximum deviation was for specimens with martensite layer and martensite-less specimens show more suitable agreement.

fn.p: Figures 6 and 8 appear in color online: http://ijd.sagepub.com

ref.citation: AghazadehJ.M.NazariA.Hamid VishkasoghehM.AbediM. (2010) Modeling Fracture Toughness of Functionally Graded Steels in Crack Divider Configuration. Modelling and Simulation in Materials Science and Engineering 18: 075007–075007.
